title: Monday, 5th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am

Markkus morning

Lemmy Afternoon

Soundbuy Morning

Stocks are down on "politics". And "cooling off after recent stock rises." And .... dunno, something about interest rates or something? Not sure you need to know more really.

Anyway, let me give myself a break from timing and get someone else to sum things up.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

If you thought last week was a shock in fixed income, just imagine what would happen if we actually saw CPI numbers consistently beat expectations on either/both sides of the Atlantic. Global bond markets are still set up for a long period of low inflation ahead, in our view.

BE11:18am

In our global 2018 outlook tour, the biggest push back to our view was that most didn’t believe inflation would misbehave as much on the upside in 2018 as we did, so I don’t think markets will be well prepared if it does.

red @Mouseletthats an individual consideration. youre looking passed the asset there.
Mouselet ooh a stop-loss just fired :|
Swedish Chef @mouselet. Move to Cambodia. Lower costs and denominated in $. Cheap beer too .Simples.
BE11:19am

One higher average US hourly earnings print -- 2.9 per cent yoy vs 2.6 per cent expected -- doesn’t make a trend but as we’ve been saying for several months now, in our view, everything is set up for higher US inflation this year ( eg labour market tightness, late cycle tax cut boost, traditional lag between growth and inflation etc ). If it doesn’t happen this year with all the forces present you’d have to tear up all your textbooks really.

Mouselet TRY; bought 289 sold 375
chopper bear am off to cambodia next month @swedish any tips ?
pfd rather hold a lump of USD as a GBP investor at the mo. Corbyn will kill the £
Lefevre purple b off another 10%
11:19 am
BE11:20am

In terms of what impact higher inflation would have. You only have to see last week’s price actions for some clues. 10yr Treasuries moved 19bps higher (+5.1bps Friday), the S&P 500 -3.85% (-2.12% Friday) and the VIX (from 11.08 to 17.31 on the week, 3.8 points higher Friday). In the process, 10yr Treasuries
hit their highest yield since January 2014, the S&P500 had its worst day since September 2016 and the VIX climbed to its highest level since the week of the Trump election victory 15 months ago. So for equity vol we’ve already bypassed the whole of the 2017 levels now in early 2018.
This move to higher inflation and higher yields probably won’t be a straight line but the risks are building that 2018 could have moments of big adjustments and spikes in vol. A reminder that our credit forecasts for 2018 are for IG to widen 25bps and HY c.100bps due to higher inflation and yields.
On this, our colleagues in rates and economics have raised their end-2019 Fed Terminal rates to 2.75% (from 2.45%) and year-end 2018 10yr US yield forecast to 3.25% (from 2.95% prior).

Mouselet swedish chef: unfortunately has Cambodian endemic diseases and Cambodian elder care
Miss Piggy #AverageWeeklyEarnings: Jan Hatzius, Goldman Sachs, said something about pay rises being a one-off. So Jim Reid correct to wait for a second number before calling a trend.

And, continuing the macro theme, UBS .....

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Pullback, not "regime shift", he says.

Mouselet Costa Rica likewise, maybe a bit more expensive but less worry that you are a weird eastern outpost of the Javan Empire
BE11:22am

And profit taking, not capitulation.

Lefevre "inflation misbehave"? They've been trying to create inflation at the Fed, now they have finally got it - with the help of full employment. Isn't this what they wanted?
Swedish Chef @chopper Don’t get naked on Facebook. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/02/cambodia-backlash-disrespectful-party-culture
BE11:22am

We see last week as a reset in asset valuations with market expectations for rates moving closer to the Fed dots, not the start of a new correlation regime. Positive equity-bond correlations historically (1966-1996) coincided with the extreme rise and fall in inflation, and a much steeper Phillips curve. Wages/hr ticked higher in Jan, but production/non-supervisory wages showed no real change in trend according to our economists. While CDS spreads did rise, cash IG spreads narrowed last week, which implies that the equity move may have been even more of an outlier.

Flaneur As the twitter pointed out this morning rising hourly wages is as likely to be because hourly pay is falling faster than hours worked.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

When economic data surprises have been positive, equity pullbacks have averaged 5%, suggesting last week's 4% selloff is close to an end. Selloffs have averaged 9% when data surprises have been very negative. After-tax paychecks will rise 2-4% this month making a sustained negative data backdrop highly unlikely in our view. Fed speak will also be key, as will Congress' ability to pass a funding bill ahead of the deadline.

BE11:23am

Valuation stuff incoming .....

BE11:23am

The combination of a selloff and revised 2018 EPS expectations on lower taxes has led to a collapse in the S&P 500 forward P/E, from 18.5x at the Jan peak to 17.6x currently. We see this valuation as a resistance level, particularly given the global growth and regulatory backdrop. Based on our valuation model, a ~100bp rates increase would lead to a ~1x multiple decline (vs 18bp last week), absent a change in growth (which has risen). Further, the difference between the earnings yield on the S&P, adjusted for tax, and a 3% 10yr is about 3%, near levels seen in the first half of 2017. We see scope for equity valuations to rise as higher rates are priced but higher growth is not.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

And the technical stuff ......

red @Miss Piggyre ahe see ian shepardson. his tweets.
BE11:24am

Despite record equity call/put option volumes on Friday Feb 2 nd , single stock volumes were above average but nowhere near levels of prior 2%+ selloffs. We see the extreme option activity representing profit taking on calls, particularly by HFs whose positioning was 2+ stdev above average; the moderate rise in skew also points to some protection buying. While HFs are very long, which points to potential for further consolidation, equity MFs and balanced funds are neutral by our measures, suggesting the overhang is not as broad as some may fear. Growth funds are also underweight, value funds o/w.

red highest since 2009. jan likely to be under reported
BE11:24am

And the income/M&A stuff .....

11:24 am
BE11:24am

More companies begin to pay out dividends this week, continuing through February, which would equate to over $60bn in implicit flows to investors that are typically reinvested. Additionally, fund flows, which have picked up in January, and buybacks are seasonally strongest in Q1; the earnings blackout period for buybacks is also ending. We see repatriation pushing S&P 500 net buybacks toward a new peak of $550bn in 2018, while M&A has already surged to start 2018 and should continue to rise.

Flaneur Lefevre - youve got the Think. The think is bad. Check in with your local govt office and make appointment to have the Think removed. Otherwise you will lose the Happy too.
BE11:25am

So buy stocks, says stock broker.

Miss Piggy what this guy? https://twitter.com/IanShepherdson. ok, ta.
BE11:25am

Our S&P 500 price target of 3150 is based on 1) mid-Nov pre-tax levels of 2550-2570 that were fair; 2) better Q4 data/earnings worth +30-50pts; 3) the direct 7.2% tax boost to EPS of 200pts; 4) 2018 EPS growth ex tax of 11% worth +280pts; and 5) a 0.5x multiple boost worth 70pts. At current levels, higher interest rates and lower tax rates are priced, but higher growth in 2018 and beyond is not. Discretionary outperformed Staples last week, reinforcing our relative view. We stay long Tech (Software & Svcs) and Industrials (Cap Goods), as higher inflation necessitates corporate investment, as well as Banks, which outperformed notably. Energy and Material performed worst and growth outperformed value despite the rise in rates/inflation.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Is that enough macro? I'm thinking yes.

Quick summary of what's at stake from Credit Suisse.

Pharma @Flaneur, as a pane of glass.
red @BonnemortTWI is i think 2 or 3% lower than after referendum
BBOC Wells Fargo down over 9% pre-market.. had missed that
BE11:31am

 The overlapping Continental European assets, Germany,
Neths, Hungary, Czech republic and Romania together makes up
c.47% of Liberty Global's proportionate EBITDA, so while Vodafone would still acquire a material part of Liberty Global, it
would be a much smaller deal in EV at $31bn (on 10.5x EV/EBITDA) vs c.$74bn to acquire all of Liberty Global.

 Potential upside for Liberty Global: Based on Friday's closing price, Liberty Global trade on 9.0x 2018E proportionate
EV/EBITDA. We increase our target price to $44 per share to reflect the increased likelihood that Liberty Global will sell further assets at a range of 10-11x EV/EBITDA, similar to that at which Liberty Global sold its Austrian business to T-mobile.

red TWI is what they use as an average
BE11:31am

Vodafone: The smaller size would allow Vodafone to pay a larger portion in cash on an improved synergies to EV acquired
ratio, implying the accretion to FCF per share could be considerable higher vs an acquisition of all of Liberty Global. We
estimated an acquisition of all of Liberty Global could be FCF per share neutral in year two in our recent analysis (see our
note, Revisiting Vodafone deal scenario), so an acquisition of only overlapping assets would likely be FCF accretive already
in year one. It further reduces investor concerns that Vodafone would do a bigger dilutive deal.
 Catalysts and Risks: Further news of results of Vodafone and Liberty Global negotiations. Q4 17 results 14 February after
US market close.
 Valuation: We now base our TP on 2/3 likelihood of a break-up with a SOTP implied value per share of $49 and a 1/3
likelihood of Liberty Global standalone valuation of $32, based on an 8.5x 2018E proportionate EV/EBITDA multiple.

LuckyStrike IGY small pop, Engie or Enel ready for it?
Bonnemort @red - maybe Iceland still on the up post-2009 then, might be outlier
Forester Not had pay rise in 5 years so trying to compensate by working 2.5% less hard each year - wonder if I am alone and if not how this might reflect in the figures?
11:32 am
BE11:33am

And interesting from Bernstein about the "continental" thing .....

BE11:33am

.... which continues to suggest that Vodafone's UK business -- and, by extension UK mobile in general -- is a hospital pass.

BE11:33am

The strategic logic of cable/mobile transactions in Europe is unquestionably sound. But with BT's UK residential business going ex-growth today, there has be some doubt on whether VirginMedia is the cause or collateral casualty. It remains to be seen whether VirginMedia can be put back on a path to sustainable growth. Vodafone UK remains a restructuring story. How can VOD and LBTY agree on the standalone value of their businesses under such circumstances?

Bonnemort @red - may drop again if AEP's telegraph suggestion of "WTO now" comes back
Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Hi there, would you have any post mortem on IWG? Given that the board and the CEO had been at loggerheads, there may have been any repercussions? Thank you very much
11:34 am
BE11:34am

(That note was late Friday, hence the BT reference. We note it here because Mr Mirchandani's very good.)

BE11:34am

If we estimate a 25%-35% premium where synergies are available, and zero control premium for VodafoneZiggo, it implies a synergy capture by Liberty of 50%-70%, and upside of USD2.10 to USD3.00 – if the deal gets done, and if it covers all the countries, and if we assume 100% synergy realization. A USD1.50 move on first news feels rather premature. Assessing the impact on VOD is woollier. From Vodafone's perspective, a transaction with Liberty Global is unlikely to translate to calculable upside in the value of Vodafone's equity on improved FCF generation prospects due to a very likely and sizeable 'hard' synergy pay-away. However, it will be a re-rating driver with the option value of revenue upside in the medium term. If this analyst is asked, then he would say that it’s a deal worth doing. So many ifs…

red @Bonnemortthats why its called trade weighted.re WTO. its a dead cert. for me. always has been. predict a large fall from oct this year if not before.
BE11:35am

One outlier here is Numis., which is growing more keen on Vodafone in part because (it says) splitting off the UK would cause dissynergies.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Buying LBTY out of Germany would double VOD's cable footprint to c.60% of the country. Because of this, cable's long and enduring value, and the total worth of Germany's market, we doubt investors will begrudge VOD if it pays a full multiple (11-12x EBITDA). LBTY thinks Germany is a 'crown jewel' but also that fixed/mobile convergence is a certainty and this favours national-scale players. We are glad VOD is not selling out of the UK as this could hurt its global Enterprise business.

BE11:37am

Numis goes to "buy", though is mostly a post-results valuation call.

BE11:37am

Skittish stock markets create buying opportunities so we raise our VOD rating to BUY. Our group forecasts and 270p TP remain unchanged. VOD service revenue growth in 3Q FY18 only met consensus expectations but prospects for sustained, much faster EBITDA growth are intact. Spectrum costs will rise in FY19/FY20 but VOD believes its long-term estimate of €1.2bn pa is still reasonable, and this is key for DPS (given also the balance sheet remains strong). It is too early to believe VOD will have to inject more cash into its Indian asset.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

............ and a tricky day to put that call out, one might argue.

Bonnemort So buy USTs!

Lefevre @Forester, don't really accept "falling real incomes" hypothesis - wages rising slower than prices. Still plenty of potential to boost real income thru cutting living expenses. That said, working 2.5% less hard is probably good if we work more efficiently . Keep slacking....
BE11:40am

The daily Andrew Lapthorne at SocGen has just dropped through.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Which is, as ever, excellent.

BE11:40am

As equity market investors digest some unfamiliar volatility, what will be concerning asset allocators is the now positive correlation between bonds and equities as bond yields rise. Or put simply, it is becoming very hard to avoid losing money. For example, as equity markets fell last week (MSCI World -3.4%) due to rising bond yields, pretty much every other asset lost money as well. This harks back to the 2008 period when the New York Times - among many others - wrote about the failure of diversification leading to much head scratching and ultimately helped spawn the alternative risk-premia industry. Given the shorter duration and relatively limited downside risk of bonds relative to equities, if the sell-off persists we expect increasing pressure to take money out of equities and rotate into bonds.

BE11:41am

Asset markets have an inescapable problem, i.e., historically low level nominal yields on a global balanced portfolio and depressed real yields at a time of low inflation. To get higher real yields from here, either inflation needs to head even lower (risking deflation), or yields rise due to falling prices. Neither outcome is very positive.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

We never know if a sell-off is part of a longer-term trend as this can only be judged ex-post, but we don't think managing an orderly decline in asset prices and the associated rise in volatility at a time of record valuations and high corporate leverage is going to be a 'healthy exercise'. In down markets, balance sheet risk is always the most important factor, and this bout of equity market weakness is proving no exception.

red @Pharmaits the lack of buying that is the worry once fed disappears. 3.04% is the prev high on the TNX. v quickly can reach 3.70-4% technically and with help of stop loss selling but u would need to have inflation backing up the break in order for it to not be a false one. ultimately soft inflation will bring bond bulls back.

These demands on cash, in particular, would seem to take the situation
closer to Sachem Head’s previous activist investments in Autodesk and CDK Global, and to our “aggressive”
Sum-Of-the-Parts scenario of 5,830p (+53% potential upside), so that shares could react positively today. We
continue to note that Sachem Head’s most successful activist investments have included tickets as high as
$785m / 5.9% stakes, and the involvement of other activist funds, so that the board could have grounds not to
consider these demands just yet (currently 3.4% interest in Whitbread ie $335m).

Lefevre @red. I went thru the op profits of IQE a year ago, each reporting unit, every 6 months for previous 2 years - came away puzzled at how they claimed to have hit profit forecast using one-offs. Sold out, premature but didn't regret
Forester Whitbread - what a stupid idea and short cut to ruining a successful business!
BE11:49am

And here's Barclays.

BE11:49am

In ‘What if?’, 3rd January 2018, we explored the potential upside associated with a Costa Sale and full opco propco separation. As we discussed at the time, we believe management is increasingly warming to the idea of a Costa sale (albeit after current turnaround initiatives have been implemented in 12-18 months). We see a very low probability of management wanting to engage with an Opco Propco separation of Premier Inn, however. As we show in Figure 2 below, if Costa can be sold at 13x 18E EV/EBITDA this would add c261p to our 3920p base case (4181p). At 15x this would rise to 4442p. This represents 10% to 16% potential upside from the current share price. In the event that management were to embark on a full sale and leaseback this would increase these values to 4747p in our upside case or 5658p in our ‘blue sky’ scenario.

Chip wafer maker IQE drifted 3.3 per cent lower to 104.4p. A report by Matthew Earl, a sellside analyst turned short seller, highlighted IQE’s poor history in generating cash and an apparent reliance on transactions with two joint ventures.

IQE is the second most-shorted stock on the London market, with nearly 23 per cent of its free float loaned out, Markit data show. Only Debenhams, with 27 per cent of its free float on loan, is more crowded by short sellers.

In short, we consider the conclusions to show a misunderstanding of the compound semiconductor industry, IQE’s position therein and its finances. The focus of the report is on two JVs established in part by IQE, one in Wales and one in Singapore. No new information has been uncovered in the report, as the finances of IQE and these two JVs are readily available via IQE’s annual report, Companies House in the UK and ACRA in Singapore. The crux of the negative report is that a significant portion of IQE’s operating profit was generated due to revenue from these JVs during 2015 and 16, enough so as to cause concern for the author.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

We disagree with this conclusion for two key reasons, namely the fundamentals and the financials. From a fundamental point of view, these JVs were not set-up as entities merely to shift funds around to benefit IQE, but rather as links between IQE, academia and other supply chain partners in order to further research and development in the burgeoning field of compound semiconductors. In terms of financials, all is disclosed in public documents which have been audited by independent accountants. As a JV partner, IQE participates significantly in the governance of the JVs, but they are separate legal entities, with their own boards and shareholder agreements. The fact that a significant portion of profit came from these two entities in 2015 and 16 is coincidental and does not signal to us anything sinister. On our estimates in 2017 and beyond, IQE’s licensing revenue from these JVs is de minimis relative to the growth coming from selling its epitaxial wafers into wireless and optical applications, including 3D sensing. IQE has already preannounced 2017 sales, with

The Singapore JV is less high profile, certainly here in the UK, than the Cardiff one, but we think it worth remembering that Win Semiconductor is another major player in the compound semiconductor supply chain. Today, it is significant provider of foundry services to the wireless RF semi industry and is also the outsourced foundry for Lumentum, making the VCSELs on IQEs wafers for the iPhone X. This relationship between IQE, Win and Lumentum is separate to that of the CSDC JV.
